comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: David Allen had a bar in the Market Square for many years and after he died it was run by his son-in-law Alexander Mills. Later it was sold to Owen Cull who had a bakery business as well. His son Owen rebuilt the bar and made a new lounge and the bakery shop was closed, the bar continuing as the MARKET BAR From lisburn.com/books/dromore-historical/Journal-2/journal-2-...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Mrs. Molly Dawson formerly Patterson from Listullycurran, farmed there with her husband. When her husband died, she sold the farm and bought a bar in the Square for ï¿½80.00 in the early 1880's. She was a relation of Mrs. R. J. Poots, and when Mrs. Dawson died the bar was taken over by R. J. Poots & Co. in 1902, he had a grocery and funeral business etc. on the premises. After R. J. Poots died it was run by his family for years. Then it was sold to Bobby Price and later to Mr. Hunter and partner and also to a Mr. Hewitt. Latterly known as THE CORNER HOUSE, the spirit licence was discontinued when it was acquired by Mr. Wm. Draffin who currently runs an estate agents business in it under the long-established local name of George Preston & Co. From lisburn.com/books/dromore-historical/Journal-2/journal-2-...

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Well that's your reputation as a Time Lord blown to pieces - giving away your secrets! Don't you know anything about preserving an air of mystery? P.S. Thank you for the limerickbyBeachcomber!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Had a quick look for the Reverend George... "The Derry Synod assembed in Omagh for its September session. The Rev. George R. Wedgwood, the recently appointed chairman of the Synod, presided..." (Ulster Herald of Saturday, 13 September 1902) Our Rev. G.R. Wedgwood presided at the marriage of Robert N. Anderson of Derry to Lydia Elizabeth Smith of Dublin at Charleston Road Methodist Church in Dublin on 16 June 1903 (Freeman's Journal of Saturday, 27 June 1903) George Wedgwood was back in Jublin a year later where he attended the Annual Methodist Conference in Dublin (Freeman's Journal of Tuesday, 21 June 1904) and he was Convenor of the Committee on Church Membership at the Methodist Church General Committee of Management meeting in Dublin a few months later (Freeman's Journal of Wednesday, 21 September 1904)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Found some good Dromore background in the 1904 Belfast and Province of Ulster Directory including:
... A market town in the County Down ... The town is improved much, and is gradually being extended. There are three factories, which give employment to a large number of hands; and one flax and two corn mills ... The markets in Dromore are rapidly increasing, and there is always a fair attendance of buyers for farm products. ... There is a market held on Saturday and Wednesday in each week, the latter day being principally for oats, grass-seed, and fowl...
Interestingly, every one of the names apparent in this photograph are listed under INHABITANTS, except for Poots!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 51439134@N00
comment._content: The Rev George R Wegwood was also a member of the Royal Society of Antiquaries of Ireland in 1896 (as shown in their Annual meeting report - www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/25508297?uid=3737536&u... ) He also presented at the fourth Ecumenical Methodist held in Torronto in 1911 on Temperance Reform (archive.org/stream/fourthecumenical00unknuoft/fourthecume... )
